importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when initial guidance was issued recommending early introduction of peanuts to infants, marking a turning point in allergy prevention practices.
When expanded recommendations for early allergen introduction were released, leading to a further decline in peanut allergy rates.
The year when updated clinical guidelines were published, recommending the introduction of peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age without prior screening.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which the implementation of early peanut introduction guidelines has led to measurable declines in pediatric peanut allergies.

keyTakeAways: Peanut allergy rates in children aged 0 to 3 fell by over 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to public health guidance on early allergen introduction.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, based on the implementation of early feeding recommendations.
The 2015 LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early peanut exposure reduces allergy risk by more than 80% and persists in about 70% of children into adolescence.
Despite strong scientific evidence, adoption of early allergen introduction guidelines was slow, with only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists following the expanded guidance in 2017.
The new research shows that early allergen introduction is being adopted and is having a measurable public health impact.
Current guidance recommends introducing peanuts and other major food allergens between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening or testing.
Safe methods include small tastes of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters, under medical consultation.
Advocates such as Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support the shift to early introduction as a meaningful opportunity to reduce food allergy prevalence nationwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early peanut exposure in infants reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies by over 80%, new research shows that real-world implementation of early allergen introduction guidelines — first issued in 2015 and expanded in 2017 — has led to a significant decline in peanut allergy rates in U.S. children. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and published in Pediatrics, found that peanut allergy diagnoses dropped by over 27% and over 40% after 2015 and 2017 respectively, with approximately 40,000 children avoiding peanut allergies since 2015. Despite initial resistance from medical professionals and parents, adoption of the recommendations has increased, and the evidence now supports that early introduction of allergens like peanuts, milk, and soy between 4 and 6 months of age is both safe and effective. This shift, backed by scientific studies such as the LEAP trial led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, represents a major public health advancement in allergy prevention.
title: New Study Shows Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S.
